articles.title: Scientists uncover a massive hidden crater in China that rewrites Earth’s recent history
articles.summary: A massive, well-preserved impact crater has been uncovered in Guangdong, revealing the signature of a powerful meteorite strike during the Holocene. Measuring 900 meters across, it dwarfs other known craters from the same era. Shock-damaged quartz confirms the intense forces involved. Its survival in a high-erosion environment makes it a geological rarity.
articles.content:
A recently uncovered and unusually intact impact crater is offering scientists new insights into how objects from space have struck Earth throughout its history.

Researchers from Shanghai and Guangzhou, China, describe their findings in the journal Matter and Radiation at Extremes (AIP Publishing). They identified the feature as the Jinlin crater, a bowl-shaped structure positioned on a hillside and protected within a thick layer of weathered granite.

A Rare and Young Crater in Southern China

The crater lies in Zhaoqing, Guangdong Province, and is one of only about 200 confirmed impact sites on the planet. Its age places it among the youngest known. Soil erosion measurements indicate that it likely formed during the early-to-mid Holocene -- the geological interval that began at the end of the last ice age roughly 11,700 years ago. With a width of 900 meters, it is the largest verified crater from this period -- surpassing Russia's Macha crater, which measures 300 meters and was previously considered the biggest Holocene impact site.

"This discovery shows that the scale of impacts of small extraterrestrial objects on the Earth in the Holocene is far greater than previously recorded," said author Ming Chen.

Clues About the Object That Struck Earth

The team concluded that the object responsible was a meteorite rather than a comet. A cometary collision would have produced a much larger crater, likely at least 10 kilometers across. What remains unknown is whether the meteorite was composed of stone or iron, a distinction that requires further study.

Remarkable Preservation and Shock Features in Quartz

One of the most unexpected aspects of Jinlin is how well it has survived. The area experiences heavy rainfall, strong monsoons, and high humidity, all of which rapidly erode rock. Even so, the crater remains clear and well defined. Inside its granite layers, researchers discovered numerous grains of quartz marked by tiny structures known as planar deformation features. These microscopic signatures are widely recognized by geologists as a hallmark of an impact event.

"On the Earth, the formation of planar deformation features in quartz is only from the intense shockwaves generated by celestial body impacts, and its formation pressure ranges from 10 to 35 gigapascals, which is a shock effect that cannot be produced by any geological process of the Earth itself," said Chen.

Significance for Understanding Earth's Impact History

Although every location on Earth is thought to have had similar chances of being hit by an extraterrestrial object over time, the evidence of past collisions does not survive equally well. Rock types, climate, and erosion patterns vary across the planet, allowing many ancient craters to vanish entirely. The survival of the Jinlin crater therefore provides an unusually clear window into events that shaped the recent geological past.

"The impact crater is a true record of Earth's impact history," said Chen. "The discovery of the Earth impact crater can provide us with a more objective basis for understanding the distribution, geological evolution, and impact history and regulation of small extraterrestrial bodies."
articles.reasoning: The discovery of a large, well-preserved Holocene impact crater in China provides significant new scientific insights into Earth's recent impact history from extraterrestrial objects. This finding has broad implications for geology and planetary science, offering a rare and meaningful contribution to understanding natural events that have shaped our planet. The article is focused, detailed, and highlights the crater's uniqueness and preservation despite harsh environmental conditions.
articles.personality_title: Scientists discover large, well-preserved meteorite crater in China
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Scientists study craters formed when space objects hit Earth to learn about our planet’s history. Most craters from recent times are small or hard to find because weather and erosion wear them away.

**What happened** – Researchers in China found a big crater called Jinlin in Guangdong Province. It is 900 meters wide and formed during the Holocene, the time after the last ice age about 11,700 years ago. This crater is much larger than other craters from the same period, like Russia’s Macha crater, which is only 300 meters wide. The scientists confirmed it was made by a meteorite impact by studying quartz minerals inside the crater.

**Impact** – The Jinlin crater is very unusual because it has stayed well-preserved despite heavy rain and strong weather that usually erodes rocks quickly. This gives scientists a rare chance to study a young and large impact site. It helps them understand how often and how big space objects have hit Earth in recent times. The crater also shows clear signs of the powerful shockwaves caused by the impact.

**What's next step** – Scientists plan to study more details about the meteorite, such as whether it was made of stone or metal. They will also use the Jinlin crater to improve knowledge about how meteorite impacts affect Earth’s surface and history.

**One-sentence takeaway** – A large, well-preserved meteorite crater found in China offers new clues about recent impacts from space on Earth’s surface.
articles.personality_title_fr: Des scientifiques découvrent un grand cratère de météorite bien conservé en Chine
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Les scientifiques étudient les cratères formés par des objets venus de l’espace qui frappent la Terre pour mieux comprendre l’histoire de notre planète. La plupart des cratères récents sont petits ou difficiles à trouver car le temps et l’érosion les effacent.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Des chercheurs en Chine ont découvert un grand cratère appelé Jinlin dans la province du Guangdong. Il mesure 900 mètres de large et s’est formé pendant l’Holocène, la période après la dernière ère glaciaire il y a environ 11 700 ans. Ce cratère est beaucoup plus grand que d’autres cratères de la même époque, comme le cratère Macha en Russie, qui fait seulement 300 mètres. Les scientifiques ont confirmé qu’il a été créé par l’impact d’une météorite en étudiant les minéraux de quartz à l’intérieur.

**Impact** – Le cratère Jinlin est très rare car il est bien conservé malgré les fortes pluies et les conditions climatiques qui détruisent normalement les roches rapidement. Cela donne aux scientifiques une occasion précieuse d’étudier un site d’impact jeune et grand. Cela les aide à comprendre la fréquence et la taille des objets de l’espace qui frappent la Terre récemment. Le cratère montre aussi des signes clairs des puissantes ondes de choc causées par l’impact.

**Prochaine étape** – Les scientifiques vont étudier plus en détail la météorite, comme savoir si elle était faite de pierre ou de métal. Ils utiliseront aussi le cratère Jinlin pour mieux comprendre comment les impacts de météorites affectent la surface et l’histoire de la Terre.

**En une phrase** – Un grand cratère de météorite bien conservé découvert en Chine offre de nouvelles informations sur les impacts récents d’objets de l’espace sur la Terre.
articles.personality_title_es: Científicos descubren un gran cráter de meteorito bien conservado en China
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Los científicos estudian los cráteres que dejan los objetos del espacio cuando chocan con la Tierra para entender mejor la historia de nuestro planeta. La mayoría de los cráteres recientes son pequeños o difíciles de encontrar porque el clima y la erosión los borran.

**Qué pasó** – Investigadores en China encontraron un gran cráter llamado Jinlin en la provincia de Guangdong. Tiene 900 metros de ancho y se formó durante el Holoceno, la época después de la última era glacial hace unos 11,700 años. Este cráter es mucho más grande que otros cráteres de la misma época, como el cráter Macha en Rusia, que mide solo 300 metros. Los científicos confirmaron que fue creado por un impacto de meteorito al estudiar minerales de cuarzo dentro del cráter.

**Impacto** – El cráter Jinlin es muy especial porque se ha mantenido bien conservado a pesar de las fuertes lluvias y el clima que normalmente desgastan las rocas rápido. Esto da a los científicos una oportunidad rara para estudiar un sitio de impacto joven y grande. Les ayuda a entender con qué frecuencia y qué tan grandes son los objetos espaciales que chocan con la Tierra en tiempos recientes. El cráter también muestra señales claras de las poderosas ondas de choque causadas por el impacto.

**Próximo paso** – Los científicos planean estudiar más detalles sobre el meteorito, como si estaba hecho de piedra o metal. También usarán el cráter Jinlin para mejorar el conocimiento sobre cómo los impactos de meteoritos afectan la superficie y la historia de la Tierra.

**Frase clave** – Un gran cráter de meteorito bien conservado descubierto en China ofrece nuevas pistas sobre impactos recientes de objetos espaciales en la superficie de la Tierra.

articles.title: Astronomers spot a rare planet-stripping eruption on a nearby star
articles.summary: Scientists have finally confirmed a powerful coronal mass ejection from another star, using LOFAR radio data paired with XMM-Newton’s X-ray insights. The eruption blasted into space at extraordinary speeds, strong enough to strip atmospheres from close-orbiting worlds. This suggests planets around active red dwarfs may be far less hospitable than hoped.
articles.content:
Astronomers working with the European Space Agency's XMM-Newton observatory and the LOFAR radio telescope have obtained clear evidence of a violent burst of material hurled into space by a distant star. The outflow was strong enough that any nearby planet in its path would likely have its atmosphere stripped away.

This burst was identified as a coronal mass ejection (CME), a type of eruption frequently produced by the Sun. During a CME, enormous quantities of charged particles and plasma are pushed outward from the star, filling the surrounding space. These dramatic outbursts drive what we call space weather, influence events such as auroras on Earth, and can gradually erode the atmospheres of neighboring planets.

Scientists had long suspected that other stars generate their own CMEs, yet convincing proof had remained elusive. That gap has now been filled.

"Astronomers have wanted to spot a CME on another star for decades," says Joe Callingham of the Netherlands Institute for Radio Astronomy (ASTRON), author of the new research published in Nature. "Previous findings have inferred that they exist, or hinted at their presence, but haven't actually confirmed that material has definitively escaped out into space. We've now managed to do this for the first time."

A Rare Radio Signal Marks Material Escaping the Star

As a CME pushes outward through the outer layers of a star and into the surrounding region, it generates a shock wave along with a sudden burst of radio waves (a form of light). Joe and his colleagues detected this brief, intense radio signal and traced it to a star located around 130 light-years away.

"This kind of radio signal just wouldn't exist unless material had completely left the star's bubble of powerful magnetism," adds Joe. "In other words: it's caused by a CME."

A Hyperactive Red Dwarf With Planet-Scorching Power

The star producing the eruption is a red dwarf, which is a much cooler, dimmer, and smaller type of star than the Sun. It differs from our Sun in several key ways: it has about half the Sun's mass, it rotates 20 times faster, and its magnetic field is an estimated 300 times stronger. Most planets discovered in the Milky Way orbit stars of this type.

The radio signal was detected with the Low Frequency Array (LOFAR) thanks to new data-processing techniques developed by co-authors Cyril Tasse and Philippe Zarka at the Observatoire de Paris-PSL. The team then relied on ESA's XMM-Newton to measure the star's temperature, rotation, and X-ray brightness. These details were necessary to interpret the radio burst and determine the nature of the eruption.

"We needed the sensitivity and frequency of LOFAR to detect the radio waves," says co-author David Konijn, a PhD student working with Joe at ASTRON. "And without XMM-Newton, we wouldn't have been able to determine the CME's motion or put it in a solar context, both crucial for proving what we'd found. Neither telescope alone would have been enough -- we needed both."

Their measurements revealed that the CME was traveling at roughly 2400 km per second. CMEs that fast occur in only about 1 out of every 2000 events on the Sun. The burst was also dense and energetic enough that any planet orbiting close to this star could have its atmosphere entirely stripped away.

Implications for Life Around Red Dwarfs

The ability of such a CME to remove atmospheres is an important factor in the search for life beyond the Solar System. A planet's habitability is often tied to whether it falls within its star's 'habitable zone', where liquid water can persist on the surface of a planet with the right atmospheric conditions. The concept is similar to the Goldilocks idea: too close is too hot, too far is too cold, and the middle region is potentially just right.

However, a star that frequently unleashes strong eruptions and extreme space weather may rob even a well-positioned planet of its atmosphere. A world exposed to repeated high-energy CMEs could be reduced to bare rock, even if it orbits at a distance normally considered favorable for life.

"This work opens up a new observational frontier for studying and understanding eruptions and space weather around other stars," adds Henrik Eklund, an ESA research fellow based at the European Space Research and Technology Centre (ESTEC) in Noordwijk, The Netherlands.

"We're no longer limited to extrapolating our understanding of the Sun's CMEs to other stars. It seems that intense space weather may be even more extreme around smaller stars -- the primary hosts of potentially habitable exoplanets. This has important implications for how these planets keep hold of their atmospheres and possibly remain habitable over time."

Expanding the Study of Extreme Space Weather

This discovery also deepens our knowledge of space weather more broadly, an area long studied by ESA through missions including SOHO, the Proba series, Swarm, and Solar Orbiter.

XMM-Newton remains a key observatory for examining high-energy environments throughout the Universe. Since its launch in 1999, it has explored galactic cores, studied stellar evolution, investigated regions around black holes, and observed bursts of intense radiation from distant stars and galaxies.

"XMM-Newton is now helping us discover how CMEs vary by star, something that's not only interesting in our study of stars and our Sun, but also our hunt for habitable worlds around other stars," says ESA XMM-Newton Project Scientist Erik Kuulkers. "It also demonstrates the immense power of collaboration, which underpins all successful science. The discovery was a true team effort, and resolves the decades-long search for CMEs beyond the Sun."
articles.reasoning: The article reports a significant scientific breakthrough: the first confirmed detection of a coronal mass ejection (CME) from another star. This discovery advances understanding of stellar space weather and its impact on exoplanet habitability, which has broad implications for the search for life beyond Earth. The story is focused, detailed, and highlights a meaningful achievement with wide scientific and societal relevance.
articles.personality_title: Astronomers confirm powerful space storm blasting from a nearby star
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Scientists have long known that our Sun can release huge bursts of charged particles called coronal mass ejections (CMEs). These eruptions can affect planets by stripping away their atmospheres. Until now, no one had directly confirmed that other stars also produce these strong bursts.

**What happened** – Using two powerful telescopes—the LOFAR radio telescope and ESA’s XMM-Newton X-ray observatory—a team of astronomers detected a clear CME from a red dwarf star about 130 light-years away. They spotted a rare radio signal caused by material escaping the star at speeds around 2400 kilometers per second, much faster than most solar CMEs.

**Impact** – This is the first definite proof that stars other than the Sun can launch CMEs. The eruption was so strong it could strip atmospheres from any nearby planets, which means many planets orbiting active red dwarfs might be less likely to support life than previously thought. Since red dwarfs are the most common stars in our galaxy, this finding changes how scientists think about where habitable planets might be found.

**What’s next step** – Researchers will use similar methods to study CMEs from other stars and learn how often these powerful storms occur. This will help improve our understanding of space weather across the galaxy and guide future searches for planets that could support life.

**One-sentence takeaway** – For the first time, scientists have directly observed a star beyond our Sun launching a powerful space storm that could strip nearby planets of their atmospheres, reshaping ideas about where life might exist in the universe.
articles.personality_title_fr: Les astronomes confirment une puissante tempête spatiale provenant d’une étoile proche
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Les scientifiques savent depuis longtemps que notre Soleil peut libérer de grandes éruptions de particules chargées appelées éjections de masse coronale (EMC). Ces éruptions peuvent affecter les planètes en leur arrachant leur atmosphère. Jusqu’à présent, personne n’avait confirmé directement que d’autres étoiles pouvaient produire ces puissantes éruptions.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Grâce à deux télescopes puissants — le radiotélescope LOFAR et l’observatoire à rayons X XMM-Newton de l’ESA — une équipe d’astronomes a détecté une EMC claire provenant d’une étoile naine rouge située à environ 130 années-lumière. Ils ont repéré un signal radio rare causé par du matériel s’échappant de l’étoile à une vitesse d’environ 2400 kilomètres par seconde, bien plus rapide que la plupart des EMC solaires.

**Impact** – C’est la première preuve définitive que des étoiles autres que le Soleil peuvent lancer des EMC. L’éruption était si forte qu’elle pourrait arracher l’atmosphère des planètes proches, ce qui signifie que beaucoup de planètes autour des naines rouges actives sont peut-être moins susceptibles d’abriter la vie que ce que l’on pensait. Comme les naines rouges sont les étoiles les plus courantes dans notre galaxie, cette découverte change la façon dont les scientifiques envisagent la recherche de planètes habitables.

**Prochaine étape** – Les chercheurs utiliseront des méthodes similaires pour étudier les EMC d’autres étoiles et comprendre la fréquence de ces tempêtes puissantes. Cela aidera à mieux connaître la météo spatiale dans toute la galaxie et à orienter les futures recherches de planètes pouvant abriter la vie.

**Une phrase clé** – Pour la première fois, des scientifiques ont observé directement une étoile autre que le Soleil lançant une puissante tempête spatiale capable d’arracher l’atmosphère des planètes proches, modifiant ainsi les idées sur les lieux possibles de vie dans l’univers.
articles.personality_title_es: Astrónomos confirman una poderosa tormenta espacial proveniente de una estrella cercana
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Los científicos saben desde hace tiempo que nuestro Sol puede liberar grandes explosiones de partículas cargadas llamadas eyecciones de masa coronal (EMC). Estas erupciones pueden afectar a los planetas al quitarles su atmósfera. Hasta ahora, nadie había confirmado directamente que otras estrellas también produjeran estas fuertes erupciones.

**Qué pasó** – Usando dos telescopios potentes — el radiotelescopio LOFAR y el observatorio de rayos X XMM-Newton de la ESA — un equipo de astrónomos detectó una EMC clara de una estrella enana roja a unos 130 años luz de distancia. Detectaron una señal de radio rara causada por material que escapaba de la estrella a una velocidad de aproximadamente 2400 kilómetros por segundo, mucho más rápido que la mayoría de las EMC solares.

**Impacto** – Esta es la primera prueba definitiva de que estrellas distintas al Sol pueden lanzar EMC. La erupción fue tan fuerte que podría quitar la atmósfera a planetas cercanos, lo que significa que muchos planetas que orbitan enanas rojas activas podrían ser menos habitables de lo que se pensaba. Como las enanas rojas son las estrellas más comunes en nuestra galaxia, este hallazgo cambia cómo los científicos piensan sobre dónde podrían existir planetas habitables.

**Próximo paso** – Los investigadores usarán métodos similares para estudiar las EMC de otras estrellas y aprender con qué frecuencia ocurren estas poderosas tormentas. Esto ayudará a mejorar nuestro conocimiento del clima espacial en toda la galaxia y a guiar futuras búsquedas de planetas que puedan albergar vida.

**Una frase clave** – Por primera vez, los científicos han observado directamente una estrella fuera del Sol lanzando una poderosa tormenta espacial que podría quitar la atmósfera a planetas cercanos, cambiando las ideas sobre dónde podría existir vida en el universo.
